title: Christian Slater regrets not taking Bram Stoker’s Dracula role over Keanu Reeves
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Christian Slater has revealed he regrets passing up the role of Jonathan Harker in the 1992 film, Bram Stoker’s Dracula.

The role ended up going to Keanu Reeves (who, according to director Francis Ford Coppola, admitted the actor’s attempt at a British accent ‘came off as stilted’) and won a bunch of Academy Awards, including Best Costume Design, Best Sound Editing and Best Makeup.

And now Christian Slater wishes he was part of it all.

Christian Slater regrets not taking Dracula role over Keanu Reeves (Picture: Nathan Congleton/NBC/NBCU Photo Bank via Getty Images)

The 50-year-old actor was in conversation with Kevin Nealon during his hugely popular segment, Hiking with Kevin. As the pair are hiking along a canyon in Hollywood, they start talking about Bram Stoker’s Dracula.

Christian revealed he wanted the titular role, but was offered Jonathan Harker so turned it down.

He said: ‘I had worked with Francis Ford Coppola before and he was getting ready to do Dracula and you know my thought was because he was offering me the Jonathan Harker role, I was like, if I’m not gonna be Dracula then what’s the point.

‘Keanu Reeves very kindly stepped into that one,’ he added.

Kevin Nealon and Christian Slater (Picture: Hiking with Kevin)

Christian said his own ‘ego’ got in the way of accepting the role in the film.

‘Those are the moments where you look back and you go boy, you know it would’ve been nice to get out of my own way.

‘So now that’s what I try to live by. I try to just get out of my own way and be open to things because ego is a dangerous thing. It can really get you into a lot of trouble and you think you’re entitled to stuff,’ he added.

The star also revealed he’s been sober for 14 years now and is ‘much happier now’.

He said: ‘By changing the behaviour, obviously it’s going to affect your attitude.’
